body: There is not an obvious connection between the outbreak of cholera in an overcrowded London neighborhood in 1854 and a Web site that shows the latest Ethiopian restaurant in your ZIP code. But for Steven Johnson the link is perfectly logical. In his recent book, ''The Ghost Map: The Story of London's Most Terrifying Epidemic -- and How It Changed
title: In a Multimedia Realm Where Book Meets Blog

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAY RIDGE; Run, Don't Walk, at 86th Street and Dahlgren Place

title: She Likes to Show Off New York From the Waterline

body: ON Columbia Street in Red Hook, where Brooklyn disappears into Gowanus Bay, there is a hole at the bottom of a fence behind a baseball field. Every Sunday in the spring, summer and fall, it becomes the city's smallest takeout window. As holes in fences go in this rusting edge of a city that is full of them, this one seems mostly unremarkable. It is
title: Home Games Seasoned With Mexican Home Cooking

title: THE HUNT; A Lot of Effort, a (Sweet) Little Home

title: GOWANUS JOURNAL; A Ship of Freethinkers, Hemmed In by Landlords

body: After struggling for more than two decades, Harvey Shomer says, he finally found his niche in the city's dwindling garment industry. Franabar Associates, corrects mistakes in bulk orders arriving from manufacturers in China -- the upside-down labels, the
title: Square Feet; A Pro-Business City Policy Backfires on a Few

body: I spent four years in Africa, but I didn't really understand the law of the jungle until I moved to Brooklyn last fall. Compared with Manhattan, Brooklyn is Big Sky country, a vast flat plain of buildings mostly only four stories tall. But behind the brownstone facades, each square block is also its own microclimate, an island of backyards. Humans
title: ESSAY; In the Jungles of Brooklyn, Nothing Can Stop Them

body: On the final day for public comment on the state's draft environmental review of the Atlantic Yards project, a coalition of Brooklyn neighborhood associations, churches and businesses will today be the latest to sharply criticize the review. The criticisms are in a report that asks why the environmental review provided no evidence for its assertion
title: More Find Fault With Atlantic Yards Review

title: Queasy Rider

title: URBAN STUDIES/PLAYING WITH MATCHES; Cold War Memories, Burning Bright

title: Quick Rescue In Fiery Crash On Expressway

body: An immature black-crowned night heron on the lookout for lunch at the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. Water in the canal is replaced six times a day, fostering an influx of wildlife. LENS

body: A window into a bygone era of New York City's downtown avant-garde was briefly opened on Monday night during a concert by the composer and electric guitarist Rhys Chatham at the Issue Project Room, a converted storage silo on the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. title: MUSIC REVIEW; Where Classic Avant-Garde Gets a Hint of Heavy Metal

body: I HAVE a theory about the F train. I think that people who ride the F train, which stops in the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, and is therefore the train of choice for dozens of writers, editors and publishers, choose their subway reading material very carefully. You rarely see the folks who get off at Seventh Avenue reading anything pocket-sized,
title: Call It Booklyn

title: 1 Killed in Motorcycle Crash

title: $25 AND UNDER; A Latin Fiesta, Near the B.Q.E.

body: VITO BUZZETTA, a bricklayer who has lived in Bensonhurst for 33 years, stood in his driveway on a recent afternoon -- hose in one hand, watering can in another -- and gestured toward a six-story apartment building under construction across the street. ''Look what they did,'' he said. ''It's too big.'' Mr. Buzzetta's opinion is a popular one in the
title: LIVING IN/ Bensonhurst, Brooklyn; An Old Neighborhood Grows Up Again

body: AT midday on the Thursday before last, 57-year-old Richard Edward Hill put on his Panama hat, picked up his hand-carved walking stick, left his trailer home in the southwest Florida town of Punta Gorda and began the journey back to his roots. Climbing gingerly aboard a Cubana bus, he settled down for the 22-hour ride to Manhattan, a trip that would
title: Beyond the Buzz, Red Hook Remembers

title: In the City, an Apartment With a View, and a Catch

body: An article last Sunday about a new hotel near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn misidentified the hotel. It is a Holiday Inn Express, not a Holiday Inn. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; Far From Tourist Central, a Hotel Opens Its Doors

title: FILM; In the Cinema Of the Street Kid, Casting at Ground Level

body: ''Half Nelson'' is that rarest of marvels -- an American fiction film that wears its political heart on its sleeve. It's a small film with a long view, and its story hinges on an unusually nuanced relationship between a white man and a black girl, each of whom has landed in harm's way. The delicacy of its lead performances (more on them later) and
title: FILM REVIEW; Teacher Has a Problem, Student Knows the Secret, And Two Lives Intertwine

body: Coroners said yesterday that they had attributed 10 more deaths in Queens and Brooklyn to last week's heat wave, bringing the toll in the city to at least 20. The victims, all of whom died of heat stroke, ranged from 52 to 99 years old, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner. All of them were declared dead on Friday. The
title: 10 More Died In Heat Wave, Coroners Say

body: As many as 13 people were possible victims of the brutal heat that pounded the city this week including 10 whose deaths on Thursday were definitely linked to the weather, officials said yesterday. The victims in New York City included a 71-year-old woman who could not afford an air-conditioner and an 85-year-old seamstress who lived in an apartment
title: At Least 10 Deaths in City Are Attributed to the Heat

body: As a heat wave neared the end of its stultifying journey through the Northeast, tens of thousands of customers lost power yesterday in scattered failures from the Bronx to Stamford, Conn. But utility officials narrowly averted a wider blackout on the East Side of Manhattan as a third day of high demand strained the electrical grid to its breaking
title: Heat Wave Exacts a Brutal Parting Toll

body: Why stage a seven-hour dance and music extravaganza and then call it ''Sundown'' and suggest that people might best enjoy it at that twilight hour? title: DANCE REVIEW; Improvisatory Caper Beguiles Even Before Setting of the Sun

body: THE finer points of dialectical theory have bedeviled many a philosophy major, but Friedrich Engels once said dialectics was such a fundamentally simple concept that any child could grasp it. title: FILM; Opposing Forces Lashed Together By Political Faith

body: MICHAEL SIVAK knows what it's like to regret buying a house. ''People's homes are supposed to be their safe places,'' Mr. Sivak said. ''When we knock
title: HABITATS/Park Slope; Finding a Co-op Where Owners Cooperate

body: GRUPO KRAPP takes its name from Samuel Beckett's ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' an immensely popular play in the troupe's home country, Argentina. title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 30 - Aug. 5; DANCE

body: In 1999 the choreographer Yoshiko Chuma happened upon a new obsession: cubes. As a shape, the cube is not particularly sexy, but the use of such movable seven-foot frames has invigorated Ms. Chuma's imagination ever since. Just as Picasso had his Blue Period, she is stuck on cubes. Her latest cube experiment is ''Sundown,'' a seven-hour
title: For Dance, a Cubism of a Different Sort

title: City Council Backs Mayor's Trash Disposal Plan

title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: REVOLUTIONARY WAR SITES; Where the Muskets Once Roared

title: Two Rescued From Cave-In at Construction Site in Brooklyn

Outside, a cursive inscription promises 200 girls onstage at the Sweet Cherry, a corner bar the size
title: The Nine Lives of a Topless Bar

body: In its latest effort to reclaim waterfront land for recreation, New York City plans to turn a half-mile stretch of contaminated landfill and crumbled piers in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn into a park with panoramic views of the harbor and the Manhattan skyline. The landfill was created in the 1970's, when the city planned to convert the
title: In the Works, Another Park For a Bit of the Waterfront

body: After being cooped up for months in giant rolling tin cans in the Persian Gulf, the sailors dock on the West Side piers of Manhattan and stay for a few days. New Yorkers see them move about in groups or in pairs, their crisp summer whites against the gray of the asphalt. The city they are visiting is different from the city New Yorkers live in,
title: Beyond Bars and Strip Clubs, City Beckons Sailors on Shore Leave

body: ON almost any given Sunday, the trumpeter John McNeil walks out of his apartment and down a few tree-lined blocks to Night and Day, a bistro on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope. Since February, Mr. McNeil has held a weekly gig in a rear annex of the restaurant with a quartet he formed with the tenor saxophonist Bill McHenry. A hangout for neighborhood
title: Brooklyn Jazz: A Red-Hot Renaissance

body: In the final reckoning, the pianist PAUL BLEY's influence over the last 50 years of jazz -- and it continues -- will be enormous. It includes figures as major as Keith Jarrett and Pat Metheny, and endless numbers of musicians who are still learning. Deeply original and aesthetically aggressive, Mr. Bley long ago found a way to express his long,
title: THE WEEK AHEAD: May 21-27; POP/JAZZ

body: I PROBABLY spend more time thinking about laundry than any New Yorker I know. That's because, unlike everyone I know in this city, I do my own laundry every week. title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; It Ain't Heavy, It's His Laundry

body: EVEN today, the event still resonates powerfully. In 1934, workers took axes to a mural depicting earnest laborers, debauched socialites and rampaging policemen that the Mexican muralist Diego Rivera had painted on the interior wall of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, facing the plaza. The artist had aroused the fury of Nelson Rockefeller by
title: The Other Battle Of Brooklyn

But now the company is entering the New York City real estate market, with five sites in various stages of development from the East Village to the Gowanus Canal
title: Square Feet; A Suburban Builder Heads for the City

title: Port Owner Says City Is Wavering on Waterfront Plan

His shop, in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn, is crammed with West African drums of every shape and size, all crowned in goatskin that Mr. Diokhane personally fetches from his native Senegal. Down below in the cramped basement, where Mr. Diokhane stretches the skins across the
title: A NEW CASE OF ANTHRAX: THE CRAFT; Drum Maker in Brooklyn Has No Fear of Anthrax

title: The City Life; The Great Cormorant Calls

title: POP REVIEW; Sounds of Prairie Sunsets

title: Head of Construction Company Is Acquitted of Bribing Union

title: HABITATS/Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; Her Carriage House Is a Stable for Her Art

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; A Muse Devoted to Six Feet Under

title: GOWANUS JOURNAL; A Ship of Freethinkers, Hemmed In by Landlords

Franabar Associates, corrects mistakes in bulk orders arriving from manufacturers in China -- the upside-down labels, the
title: Square Feet; A Pro-Business City Policy Backfires on a Few

body: I spent four years in Africa, but I didn't really understand the law of the jungle until I moved to Brooklyn last fall. Compared with Manhattan, Brooklyn is Big Sky country, a vast flat plain of buildings mostly only four stories tall. But behind the brownstone facades, each square block is also its own microclimate, an island of backyards. Humans
title: ESSAY; In the Jungles of Brooklyn, Nothing Can Stop Them

body: On the final day for public comment on the state's draft environmental review of the Atlantic Yards project, a coalition of Brooklyn neighborhood associations, churches and businesses will today be the latest to sharply criticize the review. The criticisms are in a report that asks why the environmental review provided no evidence for its assertion
title: More Find Fault With Atlantic Yards Review

title: Queasy Rider

title: URBAN STUDIES/PLAYING WITH MATCHES; Cold War Memories, Burning Bright

title: MUSIC REVIEW; Where Classic Avant-Garde Gets a Hint of Heavy Metal

body: I HAVE a theory about the F train. I think that people who ride the F train, which stops in the heart of Park Slope, Brooklyn, and is therefore the train of choice for dozens of writers, editors and publishers, choose their subway reading material very carefully. You rarely see the folks who get off at Seventh Avenue reading anything pocket-sized,
title: Call It Booklyn

title: $25 AND UNDER; A Latin Fiesta, Near the B.Q.E.

body: VITO BUZZETTA, a bricklayer who has lived in Bensonhurst for 33 years, stood in his driveway on a recent afternoon -- hose in one hand, watering can in another -- and gestured toward a six-story apartment building under construction across the street. ''Look what they did,'' he said. ''It's too big.'' Mr. Buzzetta's opinion is a popular one in the
title: LIVING IN/ Bensonhurst, Brooklyn; An Old Neighborhood Grows Up Again

title: Beyond the Buzz, Red Hook Remembers

body: An article last Sunday about a new hotel near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn misidentified the hotel. It is a Holiday Inn Express, not a Holiday Inn. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; Far From Tourist Central, a Hotel Opens Its Doors

title: FILM; In the Cinema Of the Street Kid, Casting at Ground Level

body: ''Half Nelson'' is that rarest of marvels -- an American fiction film that wears its political heart on its sleeve. It's a small film with a long view, and its story hinges on an unusually nuanced relationship between a white man and a black girl, each of whom has landed in harm's way. The delicacy of its lead performances (more on them later) and
title: FILM REVIEW; Teacher Has a Problem, Student Knows the Secret, And Two Lives Intertwine

body: Coroners said yesterday that they had attributed 10 more deaths in Queens and Brooklyn to last week's heat wave, bringing the toll in the city to at least 20. The victims, all of whom died of heat stroke, ranged from 52 to 99 years old, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner. All of them were declared dead on Friday. The
title: 10 More Died In Heat Wave, Coroners Say

body: As many as 13 people were possible victims of the brutal heat that pounded the city this week including 10 whose deaths on Thursday were definitely linked to the weather, officials said yesterday. The victims in New York City included a 71-year-old woman who could not afford an air-conditioner and an 85-year-old seamstress who lived in an apartment
title: At Least 10 Deaths in City Are Attributed to the Heat

body: As a heat wave neared the end of its stultifying journey through the Northeast, tens of thousands of customers lost power yesterday in scattered failures from the Bronx to Stamford, Conn. But utility officials narrowly averted a wider blackout on the East Side of Manhattan as a third day of high demand strained the electrical grid to its breaking
title: Heat Wave Exacts a Brutal Parting Toll

body: Why stage a seven-hour dance and music extravaganza and then call it ''Sundown'' and suggest that people might best enjoy it at that twilight hour? title: DANCE REVIEW; Improvisatory Caper Beguiles Even Before Setting of the Sun

body: THE finer points of dialectical theory have bedeviled many a philosophy major, but Friedrich Engels once said dialectics was such a fundamentally simple concept that any child could grasp it. title: FILM; Opposing Forces Lashed Together By Political Faith

body: MICHAEL SIVAK knows what it's like to regret buying a house. title: HABITATS/Park Slope; Finding a Co-op Where Owners Cooperate

body: GRUPO KRAPP takes its name from Samuel Beckett's ''Krapp's Last Tape,'' an immensely popular play in the troupe's home country, Argentina. title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 30 - Aug. 5; DANCE

body: In 1999 the choreographer Yoshiko Chuma happened upon a new obsession: cubes. As a shape, the cube is not particularly sexy, but the use of such movable seven-foot frames has invigorated Ms. Chuma's imagination ever since. Just as Picasso had his Blue Period, she is stuck on cubes. Her latest cube experiment is ''Sundown,'' a seven-hour
title: For Dance, a Cubism of a Different Sort

title: City Council Backs Mayor's Trash Disposal Plan

title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: REVOLUTIONARY WAR SITES; Where the Muskets Once Roared

title: BIG DEAL; Dumbo Is Humble No More

Outside, a cursive inscription promises 200 girls onstage at the Sweet Cherry, a corner bar the size
title: The Nine Lives of a Topless Bar

body: In its latest effort to reclaim waterfront land for recreation, New York City plans to turn a half-mile stretch of contaminated landfill and crumbled piers in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn into a park with panoramic views of the harbor and the Manhattan skyline. The landfill was created in the 1970's, when the city planned to convert the
title: In the Works, Another Park For a Bit of the Waterfront

body: After being cooped up for months in giant rolling tin cans in the Persian Gulf, the sailors dock on the West Side piers of Manhattan and stay for a few days. New Yorkers see them move about in groups or in pairs, their crisp summer whites against the gray of the asphalt. The city they are visiting is different from the city New Yorkers live in,
title: Beyond Bars and Strip Clubs, City Beckons Sailors on Shore Leave

body: ON almost any given Sunday, the trumpeter John McNeil walks out of his apartment and down a few tree-lined blocks to Night and Day, a bistro on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope. Since February, Mr. McNeil has held a weekly gig in a rear annex of the restaurant with a quartet he formed with the tenor saxophonist Bill McHenry. A hangout for neighborhood
title: Brooklyn Jazz: A Red-Hot Renaissance

body: In the final reckoning, the pianist PAUL BLEY's influence over the last 50 years of jazz -- and it continues -- will be enormous. It includes figures as major as Keith Jarrett and Pat Metheny, and endless numbers of musicians who are still learning. Deeply original and aesthetically aggressive, Mr. Bley long ago found a way to express his long,
title: THE WEEK AHEAD: May 21-27; POP/JAZZ

body: I PROBABLY spend more time thinking about laundry than any New Yorker I know. That's because, unlike everyone I know in this city, I do my own laundry every week. title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; It Ain't Heavy, It's His Laundry

body: EVEN today, the event still resonates powerfully. In 1934, workers took axes to a mural depicting earnest laborers, debauched socialites and rampaging policemen that the Mexican muralist Diego Rivera had painted on the interior wall of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, facing the plaza. The artist had aroused the fury of Nelson Rockefeller by
title: The Other Battle Of Brooklyn

body: Toll Brothers is perhaps the best-known builder of luxury homes in the country, having honed the art of upper-middle-class living into the science of large-scale suburban development. But now the company is entering the New York City real estate market, with five sites in various stages of development from the East Village to the Gowanus Canal
title: Square Feet; A Suburban Builder Heads for the City

The operation, home to 200 barges and tugs, is one of the last remnants of Brooklyn's working waterfront. Nearby, a developer has
title: Port Owner Says City Is Wavering on Waterfront Plan

body: Ibrahima Diokhane spends most of his waking life surrounded by goatskin. His shop, in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn, is crammed with West African drums of every shape and size, all crowned in goatskin that Mr. Diokhane personally fetches from his native Senegal. Down below in the cramped basement, where Mr. Diokhane stretches the skins across the
title: A NEW CASE OF ANTHRAX: THE CRAFT; Drum Maker in Brooklyn Has No Fear of Anthrax

body: The handy water taxi service that laces the five boroughs is offering wintry trips for bird watchers. Experts from New York City Audubon are in the cockpit, looking for feathered sights among harbor flows and bridge pilings. The trips summon visions of urban birders leaping aboard with New York-minute metabolism: Take me to the horned grebe,
title: The City Life; The Great Cormorant Calls

Wide-open spaces, or at least a New Yorker's cinematic
title: POP REVIEW; Sounds of Prairie Sunsets

body: The president of a New York construction company, who was accused of doing a ''corrupt dance'' with greedy union bosses, was acquitted yesterday in New York federal court of paying bribes to union officials. John Amicucci, 54, the president of DeFoe Corporation, was found not guilty of two counts of illegal labor payments after a two-week trial in
title: Head of Construction Company Is Acquitted of Bribing Union

body: IN the mid-1990's, Chris Piazza would walk the streets of Brooklyn looking for boarded-up carriage houses. ''I'd take down their addresses,'' she said, ''look up the tax records and write to the owners to see if they wanted to sell.'' She didn't hit pay dirt, so she and her husband at the time decided to move from Prospect Heights to Yonkers. It
title: HABITATS/Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; Her Carriage House Is a Stable for Her Art

title: LIVING IN/Sunset Park, Brooklyn; On the Trail of Brownstones in Brooklyn

These containers, in gleaming pink, silver, bronze or burnished
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; A Muse Devoted to Six Feet Under

title: For Whom Will the Foghorn Blow?

body: BROWNSTONES, Paul Eisemann says, will talk to you if you're willing to listen. And Mr. Eisemann, who has spent much of his adult life ministering to the needs of New York's 19th-century town houses, is all ears. What he hears, most of all, is the story of the workers who built brownstone Brooklyn and whose successors are filling the streets of
title: THE VOICE; The Brownstone Whisperer
